The summit was organised by the Federation of Industries of Greece in collaboration with the European Commission.

articles.title: Australian researchers call for action to reduce burning of plastic in developing nations
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Australian researchers call for action to reduce the burning of plastic for heating and cooking in developing nations, warning of health risks. Burning plastic releases harmful chemicals such as dioxins, furans and heavy metals into the air, which can have a range of health and welfare impacts.

articles.title: J&K's climate crisis
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) is facing its most severe climatic crisis in decades. The unusual weather patterns are affecting agriculture and horticulture, the main sectors of J&K's economy, and the ecological equilibrium of the region. The main sectors are drying up, destroyed or damaged beyond repair.

articles.title: ‘Climate change pushing up child labour, trafficking, early marriage in Sundarbans'
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Climate-induced disasters in the Sundarbans have severely impacted the lives of children living there over the past decade. Child labour, trafficking, early marriage, adolescent pregnancy, and violence are increasing. Social protection services remain inadequate, according to the study by the Kolkata-based NGO.

articles.title: World's glaciers melting faster than ever recorded
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: The planet's glaciers have lost 5% of their ice in little over 20 years, according to a major study.      .   "The planet’s glaciers have lose 5%   in little more than 20 years."

articles.title: USACE Park Ranger at J. Strom Thurmond Dam and Lake Project Describes Impact of Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Emily Klinkenborg
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene damaged the facilities at the J. Strom Thurmond Dam and Lake Project in Georgia. Park Ranger Makayla Barlow is focused on securing the funding needed to restore the facilities. Most of the campgrounds will be closed for the season.

articles.title: Scientists Have New Theory About Record Heat
articles.summary: There are fewer clouds around the equator and around stormy mid-latitude regions in the northern and southern hemispheres. Cloud cover in these regions is shrinking by about 1.5% per decade. Earth is taking in more heat than it's releasing, which drives global warming.

articles.title: Scientists Have New Theory About Record Heat
articles.summary: Fewer clouds in key regions is a contributor to global temperatures that are hotter than ever. If warming causes further cloud changes, more extreme heat is likely. Javascript is required for you to be able to read premium content on this page. It's available in your browser settings.

articles.title: Global glacier melt is accelerating, scientists say
articles.author: Fabrice COFFRINI
articles.summary: Ice loss from the world's glaciers has accelerated over the past decade. Scientists warn that melting may be faster than previously expected in the coming years and drive sea levels higher. The glaciers are important climate regulators and hold freshwater resources for billions. This page requires Javascript.

articles.title: Climate change triggers a dilemma for children development
articles.author: Joseph Prosper
articles.summary: Climate change is threatening the development, health, well-being, nutrition, education, and survival of children in Nyamagana District and other areas of Mwanza Region. Children in Mkuyuni and Mabatini Wards are already facing food shortages, floods, droughts, and waterborne diseases due to climate change. Food insecurity disproportionately affects children under five, increasing cases of malnutrition and stunting.

articles.title: APBC organises bird count in two dists
articles.summary: The Arunachal Pradesh Birding Club organised a four-day Global Great Backyard Bird Count in Lower Subansiri district and in Belo village in Pistana circle of Keyi Panyor district. The APBC is a pioneer in bird conservation in the state since 2012.

articles.title: Around Burundi's largest lake, women and children bear the brunt of floods
articles.author: WCJ Admin
articles.summary: Experts say more must be done to build resilience to landslides and other climate-related disasters. In April 2024, unusually heavy rain in south-western Burundi caused a landslide that flattened nearly 500 homes in the village of Gabaniro. A young child was killed, 2,500 people were left homeless and 500 hectares of cropland were damaged. When floods and landslides damage infrastructure and hurt local opportunities to generate income, men often leave their families to look for work, leaving women to raise children alone.
